content.body: hmm. it appears that Flash Player allows an .swf bug the user about localstorage until the user accepts
that is, if I deny, the confirmation dialog just pops up again
read that as ".swf bug" initially
asking for the confirmation is kinda pointless when the user is repeatedly tanted to allow anyway
asking users for confirmation of anything in a modal way is pointeless
jgraham: I'd hope it was much improved :)
s/tanted/taunted/
jgraham: Feedback any time before I say to not bother is welcome, though :)
hsivonen: are you a dev ? or why do you use flash ?
Maybe dialog boxes need "I don't know" and "I don't care" buttons that do the sane thing
Dashiva: Then they could remove all the other options and just leave "I don't know or care", and then they could automatically press that button for you and not have to show the dialog box at all
But expert uses know and care
*users
They're far too much in the minority to be worth catering for
By themselves, maybe, but they also direct other users, like students taking a course or employees using a service.
erlehmann: I use Flash for watching Comedy Central content.
hsivonen: that fails at so many levels ... ;)
(my guess is that they use Flash local storage for keeping track of which ads they have shown to a given user)

http://camendesign.com/code/using-abbr is it just me or is this totally wrong.
tusho: it's not just you
also the writing style is absolutely awful
why is it *totally* wrong? the main point makes sense
i couldn't read more than half of the article because of it which is why i resorted to asking ... ::P
the CSS example is questionable, though
hsivonen: I mostly looked at the examples. The spec says "The attribute, if specified, must contain an expansion of the abbreviation, and nothing else.". That is not what the author is doing
"When you read a bad document, you naturally expand the errors as appropriate in your mind."
hsivonen: that was about the title attribute of course

(heh -- from the writer's site: [['Webkit, like Gecko' in a user-agent is obscenely wrong. Why don’t user-agents say something meaningful, like “Acid 2”, “Acid 3”?]] ... the acid tests are great and all but it's not as if they'd be meaningful as a user agent string...)
tusho: Because then we're test sniffing and not UA sniffing@
gsnedders: Exactly...
And considering the Acid tests deliberately test non-standard stuff too...
tusho: Nononono, I mean, we're testing for capabilities!
gsnedders: i'm not sure what point you're trying to make as you're not making much sense to me :P
tusho: What non-standard stuff?
tusho: Me? Make sense? Why would I do that.
Dashiva: Correct me if I'm wrong but doesn't acid3 test handling of invalid code?
& markup or whatever
I don't think so. Acid2 certainly does.
tusho: The handling is part of the standard, though.

like Engine / Version (Browser / Version)
